responses_by_article.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
responses_by_article.question_text: What future trends or evolutions are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Continued/accelerated growth expected beyond 2014 → signs suggest SaaS growth will continue or accelerate
Global market reaching $12.1 billion by 2014 at 26% CAGR → strong expansion trajectory
Shift from generalized to specialized market orientation (recommended) → better alignment between licenses and client value
Evolution toward more sophisticated pricing frameworks → incorporation of previously overlooked pricing components
Increasing importance of value-based pricing → focus on delivering value to clients
Greater emphasis on usage-based pricing strategies → better reflection of vendor costs and client value
Need for improved alignment between license design and client value → sustainable competitive advantage
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'software-as-a-service (SaaS) has proliferated over the past decade and there are signs to suggest that this growth is likely to continue or even accelerate in the near future' | Page 1: 'the global SaaS market is expected to reach 12.1 billion USD by 2014, reflecting a compound annual growth rate of 26%' | Page 6: 'We suggest that it is vital for SaaS vendors to target at specialized markets in software licensing. Compared to the generalized market orientation, specialized market orientation implies that the usage variations among clients are less and the accumulation of expertise becomes relatively easy to achieve' | Page 6: 'This framework should also facilitate the identification and consideration of previously overlooked pricing components can then be incorporated into contemporary licenses for SaaS vendors' | Page 5: 'SaaS vendors seem to prefer value-based to cost-based orientation in software pricing...the focus on value-based orientation in software pricing will help them in securing sustainable revenue' | Page 6: 'usage-based pricing strategies could be attached greater importance by SaaS vendors'

responses_by_article.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
responses_by_article.question_text: What future trends or evolutions are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Continued growth of cloud adoption → By 2018, more than 60% of companies will have at least half their software and infrastructure in cloud (industrial forecast)
Disintermediation and emergence of new intermediary types → Traditional VARs being replaced by integrators/enablers who facilitate delivery, adoption and use of cloud computing
Shift from value exchangers to value co-creators → Paradigm shift in customer relationships toward open innovation and user communities
Partner service transformation → Partners shifting from technical consulting to business process consulting due to lower technical configuration requirements of SaaS
Complete SaaS adoption for new customers → ERP Co's goal as of 2014 to start selling SaaS products to all new customers in 2015, especially micro business segment
Increased co-opetition → New forms of competition where firms must collaborate with competitors and clients
Ecosystem-wide business model changes → Recognition that cloud transition affects entire business networks, not just individual vendors
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1, Section 1: 'by year 2018, more than 60% of the companies will have at least half their software and infrastructure in cloud' | Page 3, Section 2: 'the opportunities for IT vendors to sell directly to the customers and hence eliminate middle links (i.e., disintermediation). On the other hand, other types of mediators emerge: the so-called integrators or enablers who provide services to "facilitate the delivery, adoption, and use of cloud computing"' | Page 3, Section 2: 'many of the cloud vendors mentioned above operate around a user community where open innovation is flourishing, suggesting a paradigm shift from treating customers as value exchangers to value co-creators.' | Page 7, Section 5.2.2: 'the services offered by partners should be shifted away from technical consulting towards business process consulting.' | Page 6, Section 5.2.2: 'The goal as of 2014 for ERP Co is to start selling SaaS products to all the new customers in 2015, especially for the segment of micro business' | Page 7, Section 6.1: 'the technological evolution enables new forms of competition, where firms have to collaborate with its competitors and clients.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Managing a Software Business
responses_by_article.question_text: What future trends or evolutions are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Software increasingly being offered as a service → Trend toward service-based models requiring operations management
Internet and cloud computing making service components easy to include → Enabling more service-oriented business models
Swift technology advances and software evolution → Guarantees software will quickly become obsolete without constant investment
Competitors finding it easier each year to build competing products → Lowering barriers to competition
Software becoming less flexible and attractive over time → Eventually requiring frightening possibility of starting afresh
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 3, Section 'Your Processes': 'With software increasingly being offered as a service, another important thing you must manage is the operations behind the delivery.' | Page 1: 'Thanks to the Internet and cloud computing, it's now easy to include a service component into any type of software.' | Page 3: 'Swift technology advances and Lehman's laws of software evolution guarantee that, unless you constantly invest in your software, it will quickly become obsolete. Cruelly, each year your competitors will find it easier to build a competing product, while your software becomes less flexible and attractive. At some point, the frightening possibility of starting afresh might be the only viable option.'

responses_by_article.article_title: When does a freemium business model lead to high performance? — A qualitative comparative analysis based on fuzzy Sets
responses_by_article.question_text: What future trends or evolutions are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Need for larger sample size research → Future research recommended to explore more factors and verify findings with larger samples
Incorporation of entrepreneurship configuration effects → Based on top-echelon theory, future research should explore TMT perceptions and entrepreneurship influence on performance
Control variables expansion → Future research should address lack of control variables to enable generalization to other circumstances
Investigation of other freemium contexts → Whether success paths differ for other freemium business model apps beyond studied sample needs investigation
Integration of realistic factors → TMT perceptions and entrepreneurship may influence performance and should be incorporated
Data-driven learning advancement → Companies will increasingly use machine learning to analyze large data amounts to identify patterns and improve offerings
Continued growth of freemium adoption → Based on growth from 25% to 80% of App Store, continued expansion expected
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 13, Section 6: 'Therefore, future research is recommended to have a larger sample size to explore more factors.' | 'In the future, the configuration effect of entrepreneurship can be incorporated based on the top-echelon theory.' | 'Secondly, the lack of control variables limits the possibility of summarizing the results in other circumstances.' | 'First, the case sample used in this study is 45 apps from the free list of the Apple App Store, and whether the success paths of other freemium business model apps to achieve high performance present different characteristics needs to be further investigated.' | 'Last, realistic factors such as TMT perceptions and entrepreneurship may influence performance.'

responses_by_article.article_title: E-business evolution: an analysis of mobile applications' business models
responses_by_article.question_text: What future trends or evolutions are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Business models should be continuously re-evaluated over time according to environment modifications - successful features will differ in next digital revolution. E-business models will continue evolving through replicator-interactor dynamics in co-evolutionary manner. Multi-level environmental changes will drive further business model adaptations. Entrepreneurs must understand that current successful features (content apps with efficiency, lock-in, design, and complementary monetization) cannot be assumed permanent for future digital transformations.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'E-business models and their innovations are the products of evolutionary processes; from that, e-business models should be evaluated and re-evaluated over time according to the modifications of the multi-level environment' | Page 14: 'by definition, replications are not static (Aldrich et al. 2008), but they have evolved over time: the successful features that e-businesses should incorporate in order to survive the pressures of the environment are different from those of the past. Business models should therefore be investigated considering their evolution' | Page 15: 'entrepreneurs or e-business strategists in charge of defining the e-business model, should consider that the successful features in the current digital era cannot be the same for the next digital revolution; and from that, the analysis of the value sources, typologies, and value capture schemes should continue over time'
